title.narrative: Governance and State Building

description.narrative: Resilient, responsive and inclusive governance and service delivery

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: OT 2. Federal and State Parliamentary Committees are able to ensure legislation complies with international & domestic human rights standards & hold executive accountable.
Ind. 2.1 # of human rights and security related legislation developed and reviewed by the different human rights and security committees

target.value: Human Rights and security committees review 3 draft legislation per year on its compliance.

actual.value: 1 legal advisor recruited-increase in capacity to review human rights and security Laws

target.value: Human rights and security committees' 2 consultation per quarter and legislations drafted.

actual.value: Capacity to develop and review human rights and security related legislation has been increased by the recruitment of 1 legal advisor to the Human Rights Committee to the Upper House and 2 advisors attached to the House of the People and the Upper House.

target.value: Human rights and security committees' 1 consultation per quarter

title.narrative: Policies, laws and strategies for decentralisation are drafted to clarify the division of functional responsibilities among central/federal, state and local governments
1. National agreement on division of functions between three levels of government for selected sectors reached and articulated in legislation and policy
National and sub-national mechanisms are established and strengthened that lead dialogue on policies and legal framework related to local governance and decentralisation
Number of mechanisms for inclusive gender-responsive dialogue on federalism and decentralisation
Local governments deliver improved services in collaboration with central/federal, state governments and non state actors
Number of districts that develop specific measures to facilitate improved gender-responsive service delivery.
Fiscal arrangements are strengthened and expanded for service delivery and local investment at district level
1. Fiscal (rules based) transfer systems from the centre to the districts agreed
Communities (particularly women, youth and marginalised groups) engage with local governments and hold them accountable for their actions

1. Number of people reached through civic education campaigns with improved focus on women, youth and marginalised groups 2. % of people with representative participation of women, youth and marginalised groups engaging in community accountability mechanisms that express satidafaction with local government responsiveness to their concerns 3. Use of digital technologies enabled for monitoring of service delivery and local government performance
Structures and systems for inclusive local governance, planning and programming are functional
1. Local governments develop, adopt and implement participatory planning/budgeting processes 2. Local governments implement local development fund programmes compliant with systems and procedures
Representation of women in local government institutions increased

1. Number of districts with gender responsive structures in place 2. Increase in number of women in local government institutions occupying management and leadership positions 3. Number of partners raising awareness to eliminate discriminatory gender and social norms
Output 3 An independent National Human Rights Commission that is able to sustainably and effectively promote and defend human rights and address violations including against women and children

1 Multi-year strategic plan for the Human Rights Commission developed based on collected knowledge in the context of women and children’s rights in Somalia focusing on the nexus between human rights, peace and security

target.value: 10 human rights civil society actors are trained to monitor and document human rights violations.

actual.value: Civil rights organisations trained on human rights for different topics.

target.value: Multi year strategic plan for human rights developed and launched

actual.value: Human Rights Commission not yet established, process stalled at Cabinet level.

target.value: 1 civil society network per region/state and 1 main network established at the national level.

actual.value: The Human Rights Commission is not yet established as the process stalled at Council of Ministers level.

title.narrative: Output 1 Legal, policy and institutional capacity for the promotion and protection of human rights is developed and strengthened (Federal Government of Somalia, Parliament and the National Human Rights Commission

Indicator 1. 2 Support provided to one Inter-Ministerial Committee to oversee implementation of Human Rights Roadmap includding the domestication of Convention on the Rights of the Child, UPR, NAP/SVC is established /Strengthened. Indicator 1: 2 No. of draft laws and policies on the nexus between human rights, justice and security developed in line with human rights standards with the support of the inter-ministerial task force (Security and Defence related legislations/policies) Indicator 1.3: Establishment of Human Rights Commission

target.value: Strengthen capacity on Convention on Rights of Children and GBV focal points.5 key technical advisor's mainstream human rights in ministry and other line ministries.

actual.value: Agreement reached on the importance of advancing accountability of human rights violations, with commitment from all key stakeholders in criminal justice system on actions to be taken at the highest decision-making level to operationalize the commitment, as a result of a deliberations in a high-level conference with MoWHRD. 5 key advisors recruited with different areas of technical expertise – disability rights, joint programme coordination, National Action Plan on Ending Sexual violence Coordinator, translation/quality assurance and human rights legal advisor – to mainstream human rights in the MoWHRD and in line ministries

target.value: Establishment of inter-Ministerial Committee to oversee implementation of human rights roadmap. 8 draft bills.
Strengthen capacity of inter-ministerial task force and include FMS stakeholders. 2 dedicated staff embedded in Ministry of Women and Human rights. Estab Human rights Commission.

actual.value: The capacity of inter-ministerial task force was strengthened-included FMS stakeholders. 5 key advisors recruited with different areas of technical expertise.

title.narrative: A new social contract negotiated between Somali Government and the population that is more legitimate, effective, open, and accountable, providing the foundation for enduring equitable and sustainable development and peace in Somalia.
National constitution is adopted and key acts of policy, legislation and public administration have been implemented in an inclusive, transparent and accountable manner.

target.value: A finalised national Constitution that meets the needs of Somali women and men. reflects political realities. is of good technical quality and becomes a living document in society through an effective. inclusive. and accountable implementation process

actual.value: Legislative competencies for federal regional parliaments defined.

title.narrative: Somali Human Rights, Security and Justice institutions are capable and responsible for upholding human rights, including women and children’s rights

1. National Human Rights Commission is established and activated in terms of the law 2.Number of human rights complaints particularly sexual violence and violations of children's rights received and addressed 3. A treaty ratification action plan developed by Ministry of Foreign Affairs for treaties Somalia accepted to consider in the UPR process

target.value: 1. Nine Commissioners with regional, gender and clan representation are confirmed by Parliament 2. At least 50 complaints received and/or addressed including those affecting women and children are handled by the commission per year. 3. CEDAW ratified

title.narrative: Local governments demonstrate improved engagement of citizens, with an empasis on women and marginalised groups SDG 5

1. Percentage of districts with plans and budgets that reflect community priorities, including priorities for women, youth and marginalised groups. 2. Number of districts with gender responsive infrastructure
Local governments have the capacity to deliver equitable and sustainable services, promote economic development and peace SDG 16

1. Number of districts supported by programme that are documenting increase in own source of revenue 2. Proportion of the target districts' budgets allocated and spent for delivery of equitable services, disaggregated by services. 3. Population satisfaction of local government performance improves, with a breakdown in relation to services, stability and the development environment.
Policy,legal and regulatory frameworks on local governance finalised

Number of key national and sub-national policies on local governance that are approved and implemented
Number of States that have sectoral strategies guiding decentralised service delivery in terms of functions, staff and funding.
Enhanced general population knowledge on the constitutional review process, including women, youth, minority groups and the most marginalised
Percentage of the population of Somalia who are aware of the constitutional review process, its implications and how to participate in it (disaggregated by gender, age, and region).

target.value: Input from communities including vulnerable groups submitted on consitutional review process. CSO participation.

actual.value: Key political issues agreed i inter-ministerial consulttaion in February 2020.

target.value: Civic education forums organized in 3 regions with participation of communities including vulnerable groups

actual.value: Three constitutional review institutions worked in Djibouti developed and agreed on a common approach and strategy as well as a work plan for the consultation process. identified the key constitutional review issues requiring consultation. and outlined the key stakeholders to be consulted on the reviewed chapters of Somali provisional constitution

title.narrative: Enhanced capacities of constitutional key players to effectively discharge their mandate and resolve key contentious issues on all levels.
Percentage of Review Process completed in accordance with National Vision/Roadmap.

target.value: 4 thematic issues raised and discussed in consultative and inclusive forums, with e issues resolved

actual.value: FMS agreed on key political and power sharing issues

target.value:
Mechanism for national dialogue on thematic areas established.
At least 2 thematic issues raised and discussed in consultative and inclusive forums . And estimate of 33% completed

actual.value: Three constitutional review institutions worked in Djibouti developed and agreed on a common approach and strategy as well as a work plan for the consultation process.
